conclusion: To determine if accelerations are first increasing and then decreasing, analyze the v-t graphs for objects A and B.
The slope of a v-t graph represents acceleration; positive slope indicates positive acceleration, negative slope indicates negative acceleration, zero slope indicates zero acceleration.
The curvature of the graph indicates how acceleration is changing over time.
From 0 to t1, the graph for object A is concave down.
For object A, the slope is initially positive and decreasing, indicating that the acceleration is decreasing.
For object A, as time progresses, the slope becomes zero at the peak, indicating zero acceleration.
For object A, after the peak, the slope becomes negative and continues to decrease, indicating negative acceleration.
From 0 to t1, the graph for object B is concave up.
For object B, the slope is initially negative and increasing, indicating that the acceleration is increasing.
For object B, as time progresses, the slope becomes zero at the trough, indicating zero acceleration.
For object B, after the trough, the slope becomes positive and continues to increase, indicating positive acceleration.
For object A, the acceleration is first positive and decreasing, then zero, and finally negative and decreasing.
For object B, the acceleration is first negative and increasing, then zero, and finally positive and increasing.
The accelerations of both objects are not first increasing and then decreasing.
